World-Honored One!

At that time, by the Buddha's spiritual power, in the trichiliocosm, the devas of the Heaven of the Four Kings, the Heaven of the Thirty-three Celestials, the YÄma Heaven, the Tuá¹£ita Heaven, the Heaven of Delight in Transformations, the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others, the BrahmÄ Heaven, the Heaven of Meritorious Adornments, the Heaven of BrahmÄ's Assembly, the Great BrahmÄ Heaven, the Heaven of Lesser Light, up to the Heaven of Pure Abode, all these devas scattered heavenly sandalwood flowers from afar upon the Buddha, came to where the Buddha was, bowed their heads at the Buddha's feet, and then withdrew to one side.

At that time, the Buddha told Subhuti:

World-Honored One!

The Buddha told Subhuti:
When Maitreya Bodhisattva-mahasattva attains anuttara-samyak-sambodhi, he will expound the Dharma by saying that form is neither permanent nor impermanent.
'Form is neither suffering nor not suffering, form is neither self nor not self, form is neither pure nor impure,' you should teach the Dharma like this.
'Form is neither bondage nor liberation,' you should teach the Dharma like this.
'Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are neither eternal nor non-eternal' up to 'neither bondage nor liberation,' you should teach the Dharma like this.
'Form is neither past, nor future, nor present,' you should teach the Dharma like this.
Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are also like this.
'Form is ultimately pure,' you should teach the Dharma like this.ğŸ”½'Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are ultimately pure,' you should teach the Dharma like this.
Up to 'all knowledge is ultimately pure,' you should teach the Dharma like this.
SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is pure.
The Buddha said:

SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

If good men and good women uphold this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, be close to it, and contemplate it correctly, their eyes will never be sick, their ears, nose, tongue, and body will also never be sick, their bodies will have no deformities or decay, and they will never die an untimely death.

These good men and good women, on the six monthly observance days - the eighth, twenty-third, fourteenth, twenty-ninth, fifteenth, and thirtieth days - expound the meaning of this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in the presence of the heavenly multitudes. and to the Four Heavenly Kings, the Thirty-three Celestials, the YÄma Heaven, the Tuá¹£ita Heaven, the NirmÄá¹‡arati Heaven, the ParanirmitavaÅ›avartin Heaven, the BrahmÄkÄyika Heaven, the Brahmapurohita Heaven, the BrahmapÄrá¹£adya Heaven, the MahÄbrahmÄ Heaven, the Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven, the ParÄ«ttÄbha Heaven, the ApramÄá¹‡Äbha Heaven, the Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven, the Åšubhaká¹›tsna Heaven, the ParÄ«ttaÅ›ubha Heaven, the ApramÄá¹‡aÅ›ubha Heaven, the Åšubhaká¹›tsna Heaven, the Anabhraka Heaven, the Puá¹‡yaprasavÄ Heaven, the Brhatphala Heaven, the Asaá¹ƒjÃ±isattva Heaven,

the Avá¹›ha Heaven, the Atapa Heaven, the SudarÅ›ana Heaven, the Sudá¹›Å›a Heaven, the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha Heaven, the Ä€kÄÅ›ÄnantyÄyatana Heaven, the VijÃ±ÄnÄnantyÄyatana Heaven, the Ä€kiÃ±canyÄyatana Heaven, and the Naivasaá¹ƒjÃ±ÄnÄsaá¹ƒjÃ±Äyatana Heaven.

Those who study this Dharma attain the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, the fruit of arhatship, attain the path of pratyekabuddha, and attain supreme perfect enlightenment.

prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is called the great precious treasure.

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way, not knowing, not discriminating, not attaining, and not engaging in conceptual proliferation, this is called cultivating prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ. He can also pay homage to the buddhas, going from one buddha land to another, making offerings, paying respect, venerating, and praising the buddhas. SubhÅ«ti!
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ has no power or non-power over dharmas, it neither receives nor gives, it is neither born nor extinguished, neither defiled nor pure, neither increases nor decreases.

This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is also neither past, future, nor present, it does not abandon the desire realm and does not dwell in the desire realm, it does not abandon the form realm and does not dwell in the form realm, it does not abandon the formless realm and does not dwell in the formless realm.

This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ does not give to the perfection of giving and does not abandon it, it does not give to the perfection of morality and does not abandon it, it does not give to the perfection of patience and does not abandon it, it does not give to the perfection of vigor and does not abandon it, it does not give to the perfection of meditation and does not abandon it, it does not give to the perfection of wisdom and does not abandon it.

It does not give to the ten powers of the Buddha and does not abandon them, up to it does not give to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha and does not abandon them.
It does not give the fruit of stream-entry and does not abandon it, up to it does not give the fruit of arhatship and does not abandon it.

This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ does not give the dharmas of an arhat and does not abandon the dharmas of an ordinary person, it does not give the dharmas of a pratyekabuddha and does not abandon the dharmas of an arhat, it does not give the dharmas of a Buddha and does not abandon the dharmas of a pratyekabuddha.

The four mindfulnesses are empty of the mark of the four mindfulnesses, up to the eightfold noble path is empty of the mark of the eightfold noble path.

The ten powers of the Buddha are empty of the mark of the ten powers of the Buddha, up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha are empty of the mark of the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha.

The fruit of stream-entry is empty of the mark of the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning is empty of the mark of the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning is empty of the mark of the fruit of non-returning, the fruit of arhatship is empty of the mark of the fruit of arhatship, the pratyekabuddha's path is empty of the mark of the pratyekabuddha's path, and omniscience is empty of the mark of omniscience.

In this great perfection, there are also no dharmas to be seen.
Why is it so?
This dharma cannot be turned or returned, because all dharmas are ultimately unborn.
Why is it so?
This emptiness cannot be turned or returned, the characteristic of no-sign cannot be turned or returned, and the characteristic of no-action cannot be turned or returned.

If one can expound the prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ in this way, teaching, illuminating, revealing, discerning, manifesting, and explaining it in an easy way, one who can teach in this way is said to be expounding the prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ purely, and there is no one who expounds, no one who receives, and no one who realizes.
